posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: Over the years, I’ve often wondered why many teams prefer using aluminum over polycarbolic as the belly pan material, given its popularity compared to our previous use of polycarb.

posts.name: wyatt
posts.cooked: Our team uses this material because we have plenty of it, although sometimes it’s lighter than needed. We aim for around 1/8 inch or even thinner, such as what we use here. This thickness allows us to mount various features directly onto our belly pan—for example, the climb winch was installed there, though it wasn’t our top priority.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: Two main benefits of increased stiffness and weight distribution include enhanced structural integrity and improved stability. For increased stiffness, robots with corner-biased swerve modules face challenges due to long unsupported frame rails connected by few bolts, necessitating materials like aluminum for better rigidity. Additionally, extra mass added to the brainpan or bellypan lowers the center of gravity, boosting stability and reducing tipping chances, often achieved by teams using steel or solid steel components.

posts.name: Sean Paxman I 9191
posts.cooked: Typically, you want as low a center of gravity as possible, so having an ali or even a steel bellypan can help a lot with this. Sometimes, you might also consider mounting things like gearboxes to the bellypan; however, a rigid ali is much better than polycarb in this case. We use a 25mm ali billet drivebase to improve drivebase rigidity, lower the center of gravity, and provide options for custom mounting and wire routing solutions.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
This May be the last year polycarb bellypans remain relevant. With SystemCore arriving next year (26–27, possibly used at Worlds this season), aluminum emerges as the primary choice due to its heat-sinking properties.

A hybrid option exists—a split bellypan—and they can also be mounted on the superstructure, similar to how the Radio does it.

We've only tested aluminum bellypans this far. Initially considering a polycarb suggestion for this year, I now think either reconsidering or proceeding with it is wise.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked: I hate to stray off topic here, but where have you heard this? I’ve been trying to keep current on all the SystemCore discussions, but appear to have missed this. Without derailing too much, I find it peculiar that FIRST For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology would consider changing such a critical/core component (far more so than when they did this with the radio’s in 2024) for teams at Worlds.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: Involving past innovations, the new radio is a prime example. Incorporating 'possible' for a reason.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.cooked:
We tried a belly pan for the first time this past season. We used 1/8-inch aluminum and cut out squares in the corners for the swerve modules. What I learned as the most useful aspects of the belly pan include:  
- A low center of gravity: We play a lot of defense, and having a low center of gravity is crucial. Almost half our weight was in our drivetrain, making it nearly impossible to move against.  
- Protection: Although rare, the belly pan stopped game pieces and other robots from damaging ours from below.  
- Easy installation: Almost every component of our robot was attached to the belly pan, simplifying removal processes with just a few bolts.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I. Can’t wait! Event Information
We shared a blog post about a month ago with some championship information. Today, we’re excited to share a few more updates and reminders. The FIRST Robotics Competition Championship Information webpage has additional in…
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: We tested a polycarb bellypan last year and an aluminum one this year. One of the key advantages was its durability and stiffness, with no major issues arising from either. The aluminum pan had superior heat sinking capabilities, which was beneficial despite its lighter weight limiting our ability to modify it frequently during construction and competition setup. Once the aluminum pan was machined early in the season, adjustments became difficult due to limited drilling options, but overall, we managed without needing significant changes throughout the season.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: There is zero chance of switching to SystemCore next year. The radio was upgraded due to known problems with older models in busy areas like the eight simultaneous fields at Champs. RoboRIO doesn’t face these issues, so such a significant switch isn’t warranted. Additionally, beta testing will continue into the next season before its release in 2027, meaning users won’t be operating an untested device.

reply_to_user.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: We’ve run both types. Having a bellypan significantly increases chassis stiffness. The largest benefit comes from connecting the corners, though adding perimeter beams also enhances side impact resistance. Comparing materials—aluminum, polycarb, and steel—is largely dependent on your build process. Steel is typically heavier and serves as ballast, while aluminum and polycarb have their own advantages. Polycarb bellypans tend to be thicker than aluminum ones, with 1/16" aluminum proving quite sturdy compared to the more flexible 1/16" polycarb. The X brace relies on corner connections, utilizing tensile strength, whereas side impact requires additional material for stability. For lightweight designs, consider leaving solid perimeter beam areas, suggesting widths of at least 2" or up to 3". For more complex builds, aim for a triangular profile.

posts.name: Emerson OHara
posts.cooked: This! I’m surprised people don’t talk about this more. Even a 1/16" aluminum shear panel connected on all 4 edges adds an incredible amount of stiffness to the frame of a robot.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Using a steel belly pan means less concern about frame flexing and keeping the center of gravity low, though you’ll need a smaller, lighter bot overall.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: This is what I was referring to. I do agree that this is a HUGE if. Too much rewiring unlike the radio. This is why I said it is a ''HUGE if'' above. The complexity of rewiring a bot (maybe not a KoP) for Worlds would be an issue. Especially with a minimum of a week turnaround. We are talking about FIRST! It will still require an aluminum mount or bellypan/brainpan for mounting. Much like the radio, it will need a heatsink. PC will not work for it...get used to using aluminum...if you aren't already.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
For many teams, the best option remains a 1/2-inch-thick sheet of plywood or MDF. At this thickness, you achieve good stiffness and durability while significantly reducing manufacturing complexity and costs compared to aluminum—just 10% of aluminum’s price or polycarbonate. Its affordability allows for easy implementation of significant design changes without unnecessary expense.

Some advantages include no electrical conductivity, minimal metal shavings when drilling holes, and the ability to screw down small items like cable clips directly onto surfaces using wood screws instead of bolts. Last year, we used 3/4-inch MDF to create custom pockets for equipment mounts and cable channels with a CNC router.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Teams have often switched to steel pans and/or tubes. I believe there was even a team with tungsten in their robot in 2023 if I remember correctly.

posts.name: Aiden S
posts.cooked: Zaque switched to steel pans. They've been using .25" A36 steel for our bellypans since 2024. The added stiffness and lowered COG are significant improvements, particularly useful given the challenges posed by bent chassis rails last year. These pans typically weigh around 30 lbs. We hope you enjoy the product!

posts.name: topgun
posts.cooked: The steel and aluminum teams aren’t concerned about electrical conductivity; the electrical components are effectively separated from the belly pan.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: No special isolation efforts. Remember that the robot power must be isolated from the frame. There is no built-in frame grounding in the system.

participants.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
